ver_20120624/Twitter/oauth.py

00001 import tweepy
00002 
00003 # == OAuth Authentication ==
00004 #
00005 # This mode of authentication is the new preferred way
00006 # of authenticating with Twitter.
00007 
00008 # The consumer keys can be found on your application's Details
00009 # page located at https://dev.twitter.com/apps (under "OAuth settings")
00010 consumer_key="2YIdiuX1g8GyCGu0bkl2w"
00011 consumer_secret="NQm7aC0R7yYNyIgIGp9YkVl5whgqLr7yhNM7n13sCso"
00012 
00013 # The access tokens can be found on your applications's Details
00014 # page located at https://dev.twitter.com/apps (located 
00015 # under "Your access token")
00016 access_token="231725785-cKJ1FsH5YJ04wGybnQ21brhWsT6kwb5X7rVPrncM"
00017 access_token_secret="21fOvYK2ZWoKLNVN0avIRxX4ml9e4lr0tTZAhurpDM"
00018 
00019 auth = tweepy.OAuthHandler(consumer_key, consumer_secret)
00020 auth.set_access_token(access_token, access_token_secret)
00021 
00022 api = tweepy.API(auth)
00023 
00024 # If the authentication was successful, you should
00025 # see the name of the account print out
00026 print api.me().name
00027 
00028 # If the application settings are set for "Read and Write" then
00029 # this line should tweet out the message to your account's 
00030 # timeline. The "Read and Write" setting is on https://dev.twitter.com/apps
00031 #api.update_status('Updating using OAuth authentication via Tweepy!')
00032 public_tweets = api.friends_timeline()
00033 for tweet in public_tweets:
00034     t_user = tweet.user
00035     print t_user.name
00036     print tweet.text
00037     print '\n'
